Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Computationally Efficient Analytic Reconstructions via Embeddings and Sparsity for Non-Linear Dynamic Imaging Problems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
With the development of low cost, high endurance uninhabited vehicles, it is now possible to acquire imaging data persistently over long periods of time and space using multiple distributed sensors. Such persistent multi-pass sensing systems have several advantages over single-pass systems including the ability to monitor a dynamic medium, wider spatial coverage, increased resolution and the ability to acquire three or higher dimensional information. While such persistent systems have the potential to revolutionize sensing and imaging across many domains of applications, one of the fundamental bottlenecks for the deployment of these systems is the challenges in image formation: First, the reconstructions of 3D deformations, velocity fields and imaging in unknown complex environments are highly non-linear large scale inverse problems. Secondly, such systems can acquire hundreds of terabytes of data daily and forming a standard image using even a single-pass data cannot currently be done in real-time.

This project develops a unified mathematical framework and new classes of novel, computationally efficient analytic image reconstruction methods to address these large scale, computationally demanding, non-linear inverse problems. Central to our development is the synergistic combination of inverse scattering theory, sparse signal recovery methods and microlocal analysis. Our research involves the following topics: (i) Development of accurate forward models for 3D deformation-rate imaging, velocity imaging and imaging in unknown heterogenous environments using multiple sensors. (ii) Reformulation of the resulting nonlinear problems as linear problems by embedding them into larger dimensional spaces coupled with sparsity constraints. (iii) Design of analytic, computationally efficient methods for inversion by synergistically combining ideas from microlocal analysis and sparse signal recovery methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Radio Frequency (RF) sensors deployed on multiple small uninhabited vehicles have a range of potential applications. Some of these include persistent monitoring of the nation's infrastructure and borders. Such sensing systems can monitor dynamic phenomena and provide information on ground subsidence, movement of bridges and dams, and border crossings day and night from very long ranges. However, a number of fundamental challenges need to be addressed for the practical realizations of such systems: first, the determination of ground deformations and velocities is a highly nonlinear and computationally demanding problem. Secondly, such persistent systems can acquire hundreds of terabytes of data and even a single image cannot be currently formed in real-time.

In this project, we developed computationally efficient methods to extract information from a dynamic environment to determine ground reflectivity, velocities of moving objects and ground subsidence. We compared our results with existing methods and demonstrated the performance of our methods analytically and numerically. We also tested our methods using the synthetic aperture radar data collected by TerraSAR-X from New Orleans area. We disseminated our results in scientific journal and conference papers. Finally, the project provided partial support for the education of four graduate students, two of whom received their doctoral degrees and joined nation's premier research laboratories.
